titleStmt.title: A song of Inana and Dumuzid (Dumuzid-Inana Z) -- an English prose translation

publicationStmt.distributor: The Electronic Text Corpus of Sumerian Literature

address.addrLine: The Oriental Institute, University of Oxford, Pusey Lane, Oxford OX1 2LE, UK, email etcsl@orinst.ox.ac.uk, http://etcsl.orinst.ox.ac.uk

seriesStmt.p: The Electronic Text Corpus of Sumerian Literature aims to make accessible over 400 literary works composed in the Sumerian language in ancient Mesopotamia during the late third and early second millennia BC. The works are in Sumerian composite transliteration and English prose translation with bibliographical information on each composition.

sourceDesc.p: Sources are listed in the header of the composite text

div1.p:
My own mother gave birth to me for your sake, my Ningal gave birth to me for your sake. &X;&X;, my beloved heart will come. &X;&X;, my beloved heart will come there. May &X;&X; come to me (?), and I will rejoice over him. May Dumuzid come to me (?), and I will rejoice over him.
Dumuzid &X;&X;

Let us embrace, my bridegroom! Come, let us rejoice in play! Let us embrace, my Ama-u&c;um! Come, let us rejoice in play! Friend of An, lord, my heart's desire, cheering the mood, gladdening the heart: may you be our sun god! I will go to the lord, I will talk with him, I will say to the lord of my heart:

p.q: &X;&X; with Enlil, and my father, Suen, chose you in his heart. I myself chose you in my heart; you are the man of the heart. He has placed on your head for me the good headdress and the holy crown. You shall stand in service before the great gods, the Anuna gods who shine forth radiantly. Let us embrace, my bridegroom! Let us lie on my flowered bed! Let us embrace, my Ama-u&c;um! Let us lie on my flowered bed!
